title: Guy Mannering; or, The Astrologer - Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: This chase, in which the fish is pursued andstruck with barbed spears, or a sort of long-shafted trident, called awaster, is much practised at the mouth of the Esk and in the other salmonrivers of Scotland.

title: The hills of home,
author: Watt, Lauchlan McLean.
snippet: To the south, too, they beheld a deep-shaded amphitheatre of heather and bracken; the course of the Esk, near Penicuik, winding about at the foot of its gorge; the broad, brown expanse of Maw Moss; and, fading

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: He could not have come at a better time he came quite unannounced, unintroduced, so suddenly that Katie made an outcry almost of terror one moment, nobody with her but the Esk, and the roses, and her own thoughts not a shadow on the grass, not a step on the road.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: The elder sister liked him heartily, knew that he would be kind to her orphans, believed him every thing that was good in man ; but while she reasoned with herself, the color wavered upon her cheek, and some where in heart a voice, which might have been the Esk river, so closely its whisper ran with her thoughts, kept saying, " Dinna forget me, Katie !" till, by dint of persis tence, all the other meditations yielded, and this, with a triumphant shout, kept the field.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: So she took up her work, put her thread and scissors in her pocket, and went out to the garden to sit on a low garden seat, with the grass under her feet, and the trees over her, and sweet Esk singing close at hand, thinking it might be easier to pursue her occupation there.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: Her companion made no answer ; and in the little pause which ensued, the Esk, and the roses, and the moonlight came in as a sweet unconscious chorus, but a chorus full of whispers which struck deeper than those quiet words of quiet age.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: This little house stood upon a high bank of the river Esk, just after that pretty stream had passed through the pretty village of Lasswade.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: But theyhad no sooner crossed the Esk than he formed theinvestment of Carlisle, in which the Highlandershad left a garrison of about 300 men.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: By means of this contrivance, ourarmy passed the Esk in an hour's time, without losing a singleman; and a few girlB, determined to share the fortunes oftheir lovers, were the only persons who were earned away bythe rapidity of the stream.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: 3 " The Esk, which is usually shallow, had been swelled bvan incessant rain of four days to a depth of four feet.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The Scottish army left Carlisle upon the 20thof December, and effected their retreat into Scotland by crossing the Esk at Langtoun; the riverwas swollen, but the men, wading in arm in arm,supported each other against the force of the current, and got safely through, though with somedifficulty.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: They formed in one narrowcolumn, keeping the high ground from Duddingston towards Musselburgh, where they crossed theEsk by the old bridge, and then advanced to theeminence of which Carberry hill is the terminationto the south-west, near which, about Musselburghor Inveresk, they expected to meet the enemy.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " The space betwixt the (waters of) Esk and the Sark," Bays Pennant," bounded on the third side by the march dike, whichcrosses from one river to the other, seems properly to belong to Scotland ; but having been disputed by both crowns,was styled the DebaUable Land.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: TheScots attempted no farther resistance, and theslaughter was very great, because the river Esklay between the fugitives and any place of safety.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Confiding in the numbers of his army, the Scottish Regent (Earl of Arran) crossed the Esk, andthus gave the English the advantage of the ground,they being drawn up on the top of a sloping eminence.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: They posted their army behind the river Esk, nearMusselburgh, a village about six miles from Edinburgh, and there seemed determined to await theadvance of the English.
